questions.question_text: A technician is setting up a wireless network in a small, crowded office and wants to minimize Wi-Fi access. Which of the following security settings should the technician enable?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Allow list
Here's why:

 Allow list (also known as a whitelist): This setting will restrict network access to only specific devices by their MAC addresses or other identifiers. By enabling an allow list, only approved devices can connect to the wireless network, effectively minimizing unauthorized Wi-Fi access in the crowded office.

questions.question_text:
A technician is configuring a workstation's security settings, and the following options are available:
• Account lockout policy
• Group policy
• Two-factor authentication
• Password complexity requirements
• Firewalls
• User accounts
• Access control lists
• Antivirus software

Which of the following settings should the technician configure to deploy strong password enforcement across the enterprise?

discussion.content: Keywords are,"to deploy"

Selected Answer: B
Group policy is used to centrally manage and configure security settings, including password complexity requirements, for all users in an enterprise environment. Through group policies, administrators can enforce strong password policies (e.g., length, complexity, expiration) on all workstations and accounts within the domain.

Selected Answer: B
It is absolutely not A. Account lockout policies simply prevent you from reattempting to login after repeated failed logins, it has nothing to do with enforcing strong passwords.

Group policy can be used to set password requirements across the enterprise among many other things.

Selected Answer: A
It should be A . Account lockout policy

Selected Answer: C
Thought it was C initially lol. ChatGPT says: Mount the ISO file: An OS installation file is often provided as an ISO file, which is a disk image containing the installation files. To access and run the installation, the technician needs to "mount" the ISO, which makes it appear as though it's a physical disk or drive. On most modern operating systems (e.g., Windows, macOS, Linux), ISO files can be mounted directly without needing additional software.

Selected Answer: B
It is implied that the OS installation file is an ISO as almost all of them are. You need to mount an ISO file in order to run it.

Selected Answer: B
It's B

Selected Answer: C
Another horrible CompTIA question.

I choose C because the question doesn't say anything about ISO.

comments.content: I have never seen an OS installation file that was not an ISO. Should be "B"

questions.question_text: A technician downloaded an OS installation file but is unable to run it. When the technician tries to open the file, a message indicates no software is installed to run this file. Which of the following should the technician do next to attempt to access the OS file?

An organization is centralizing support functions and requires the ability to support a remote user's desktop. Which of the following technologies will allow a technician to see the issue along with the user?

comments.content:
MSRA is Microsoft Remote Assistance, which would satisfy the prompt of the question to assist a user remotely. This allows multiple connections for troubleshooting / guidance purposes.

In the options in this specific question, VNC allows screen sharing which would also allow the technician to assist the user by seeing what is on their screen.

RDP is primarily used if you *were* the user attempted to connect to a remote workstation. It's primarily a single user connection.

discussion.content: Took 1102 today and this question was on the exam but VNC was replaced with MSRA (Microsoft Remote Access)

Selected Answer: B
VNC / MSRA
"allow a technician to see the issue along with the user"
Why does CompTIA give more than 1 correct answer as an option?

Selected Answer: B
VNC (Virtual Network Computing) is a technology that allows a technician to see and control a remote user's desktop.

Selected Answer: B
Being a centralized support function, VNC would make sense being that it is assigned for thin clients connecting to a central host server.

comments.content: Yeah i agree, it also says to see the issue with the user which RDP does not allow you to do

discussion.content: VNC and MSRA both allow screen sharing.

Selected Answer: B
RDP will block the Users screen while the technician works on the device.

Selected Answer: B
It's VNC

VNC is essentially a screen-sharing protocol and is ideal for collaboration sessions which include presentations and training, as well as remote technical support functions. Each logged-in client can view and interact within the same session. RDP on the other hand does not allow concurrent logins and a new login will automatically force a previous session to log off.

comments.content: If VNC is an alternative for RDP, why not choose RDP for the answer?

End of the question states "allow a technician to see the issue along with the user" - that's the key. RDP logs you in, but force logs off the current user. And they get a blank lock screen on their end so they can't see what you're doing. VNC allows screen sharing - use it all the time at work as desktop support.

discussion.content:
There are alternatives to using RDP for remote access. For example, in macOS, you can use the Screen Sharing feature for remote desktop functionality. Screen Sharing is based on the Virtual Network Computing (VNC) protocol. You can use any VNC client to connect to a Screen Sharing server.

VNC itself is a freeware product with similar functionality to RDP. It works over TCP port 5900. Not all versions of VNC support connection security. macOS Screen Sharing is encrypted.

Selected Answer: A
A. Setting the boot order
Here's why:

 Setting the boot order: The first step in installing an operating system on a new computer is to ensure that the computer is set to boot from the correct device, such as a USB drive, DVD, or network location, where the OS installation media is located. This is done by adjusting the boot order in the BIOS or UEFI settings.

Selected Answer: A
It's A. Formatting happens during the installation.

Selected Answer: B
Prepare your installation media. ...

questions.question_text: A technician is installing an operating system on a new computer. Which of the following is the first step of the process?
